title: _.get() support for a "named index" for defining the path

Documentation of pick is not complete
Multiple agrument iteratee breaks lazy evaluation
body:
_.VERSION
"4.17.4"

`_(_.range(10)).map((x) => { console.log(x); return x }).find(x => x == 3)`
Outputs 0, 1, 2, 3 as it expected, but:
`_(_.range(10)).map((x, i) => { console.log(x); return x }).find(x => x == 3)`
prints 10 numbers. 

The difference just in an additional argument to the map functions callback.
It seems to me that lazy evaluation is broken in the second case. I can't find any reason in documentation.

title: IsMatchWith, MergeWith, ... not calling customizer for initial Arrays
body:
With the latest lodash available via npm, 4.17.4, I found a strange behaviour possibly affecting the *With methods, such as isMatchWith or mergeWith. If arrays are passed at the top level, they don't match and the customizer is not called with the array itself...

Code:
`_.isMatchWith(myTgtArray, mySrcArray, myCustomizer); `

Expected:
- should match if both array contains the same elements in different order
- myCustomizer to be called with myTgtArray and mySrcArray as whole, and then possibly with the pairs of elements inside the arrays

Actual:
- does not match / false
- myCustomizer is called only with the pairs of elements inside the arrays

Workaround with Dummy Wrapper:
`_.isMatchWith({array: myTgtArray}, {array: mySrcArray}, myCustomizer); `

Something similar also happen with mergeWith...
`_.mergeWith(myTgtArray, mySrcArray, myCustomizer);`
     
I apologize if I did miss something obvious. Have a nice day

title: assignIn_1.default is not a function
body:
My env is:
TypeScript 2.4.2
Angular 4.4.1
types/lodash-es: ^4.17.0
lodash-es: ^4.17.4

When I import the `assignIn` method everything is ok.
`import assignIn from "lodash-es/assignIn";`
But if it's called after the build I'm receiving the following error 
`JS ERROR TypeError: assignIn_1.default is not a function. (In 'assignIn_1.default({}, {...},{...})', 'assignIn_1.default' is undefined)`

I see that in the compiled js file it is required like that `assignIn_1 = require("lodash-es/assignIn")` and if I call it manually in the console `assignIn_1(...,...)` it works fine, but where I used it is called like that `assignIn_1.default()` which throws the error.

title: Feature Suggestion: _.uniform
body:
I've found the following function quite useful when summarising collections and validating user input;
```
_.uniform([1,2,3])                    // true
_.uniform([1,"2",3])                // false
_.uniform([1,null,3])                // false
_.uniform([1,2,3], 'number');  // true
_.uniform([1,2,3], 'string');     // false

const even = d => !(d%2)
_.uniform([1,3,5], even)         // false
_.uniform([2,4,6], even)         // true
```
Every time I need to use it I always assume it'll be in lodash and then find that it isn't and end up writing it as either an independent function or a mixin. This time I thought I'd raise an issue to suggest merging it into core. What do you think?

title: Feature: Batched function
body:
`batch(fn: Function, size: Number, interval: Number) => Function` 

Takes a function and returns a batched function. Invoking it multiple times will automatically batch and call it

```js
const batchedLog = _.batch(console.log, 2, 1000)

for (var i = 0; i < 5; i++) {
  batchedLog(i);
}

/* Output
00:00
1
2
00:01
3
4
00:02
5
*/
```

title: Adds _.sign
body:
Adds `_.sign`, which returns a number representing the sign of a number. This method matches the functionality of [`Math.sign`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Math/sign) which is not available in IE.

Due to the changing repo for v5 I could not see a way to add unit tests but I have tested this logic: https://jsfiddle.net/a8dkzjfx/2/

title: fp.reduce reuses accumulator when currying
clone does not copy array properties
body:
Consider following code

```
let a = [1, 2, 3]
a.specialFlag = true
let b = _.clone(a)
b.specialFlag // => undefined
```

Adding non-numeric keys to array is rare yet valid use case. Correct behaviour for `clone` would be to copy them too.

Happy to contribute with pull request, if this gets accepted.

title: set unexpected behaviour with keys looking like numbers
body:
Consider following code:

```js
let a = {}
_.set(a, ['prefix', '47'])
_.keys(a.prefix).length
```

Expected value: 1
Actual value: 48

It is because lodash tries to be too clever by guessing that `'47'` can be coerced to number and so instead of object, it creates an array.

This is confusing and may cause bugs that are hard to debug, because they show up only when string key can be parsed as integer.

I would suggest to create an array only if the key is number, not in the cases where it can be parsed as a number.

This may create an issue with `_.keys` method which returns array of strings even for arrays.

This may be considered ok as `_.keys` is defined on Objects and not general collection, or it may be modified to return numbers for arrays. In a similar fashion that native `Array.keys()` works.

title: Is not there a deep alternative of assignIn?
body:
As we know, merge is just like `_.assign` except that it recursively merges own and inherited enumerable string keyed properties of source objects into the destination object.

But what about deep alternative of `_.assignIn`?

title: Allow cond to accept not only functions
body:
Right now `_.cond` works only for the pairs of functions:
```js
const person = 'Roy'

const makeAGift = _.cond([
  [name => name == 'Helen', _.constant('There is a bouquet of flowers waiting for you!')],
  [name => name == 'Roy', _.constant('There is a new boots for you!')],
  [_.stubTrue, _.constant('Here, take some candies')]
])

makeAGift(person)
```

Proposal is to add an ability to pass non-function values as the first and the second argument of the tuple

Consider naming
```js
const condFn = _.cond([
  ...,
  [fn1, fn2],
  ...
]

condFn(arg)
```

For the `fn1` proposed behavior is
* In case if `fn1` and `arg` are primitives - use `() => fn1 === arg` instead of `fn1`
* (optional) In case if `fn1` is a regex and `arg` is a string - use `() => arg.match(fn1)` instead of `fn1`
* (optional) In case if `fn1` is a string and `arg` is a regex - use `() => fn1.match(arg)` instead of `fn1`
* In any other case - use as `_.identity(fn1)` (like for `_.filter` and others)

For the `fn2` proposed behavior is
* If `fn2` is not a function - use `() => fn2`
* If second argument is a function - use `fn1RunResult => fn2(fn1RunResult)`

In this case initial example could looks like
```js

const person = 'Roy'

const makeAGift = _.cond([
  ['Helen', 'There is a bucket of flowers waiting for you!'],
  ['Roy', 'There is a new boots for you!'],
  [_.stubTrue, 'Here, take some candies']
])

makeAGift(person)
```

title: Missing modules
body:
The following modules are imported from `.internal` but don't exist:

* `createAssigner`
* `createFind`
* `createWrap`
* `customDefaultsAssignIn`
* `replaceHolders`

The above modules are imported in the following public modules:

* `ary` imports `createWrap`
* `assignWith` imports `createAssigner`
* `bindKey` imports `createWrap` and `replaceHolders`
* `curry` imports `createWrap`
* `curryRight` imports `createWrap`
* `findLast` imports `createFind`
* `merge` imports `createAssigner`
* `mergeWith` imports `createAssigner`
* `template` imports `customDefaultsAssignIn`

-----

The following public modules are imported but don't exist:

* `assignInWith`
* `findIndex`

The above modules are imported in the following public modules:

* `find` imports `findIndex`
* `template` imports `assignInWith`

title: 'map' type mismatch
body:
## Expected behavior:

`map` should return the same functor-ish type. Mapping an object should return an object.

```
import _ from "lodash/fp";

_.map(v => v.toUpperCase(), { kek: 'bur' }); // returns { kek: 'BUR' }
```

## Actual behavior:

`map` returns an array when mapping objects.

```
import _ from "lodash/fp";

_.map(v => v.toUpperCase(), { kek: 'bur' }); // returns ['BUR'] :(
```

I know that `mapValues` exists, but it doesn't make sense having two maps when only one `map` is the correct `map`.

title: The default iterator for `_.find()` does not seem to be identity as per documentation
body:
I was surprised that `_.findIndex([{a:1}], {a:1});` returns `0` rather than `-1`, considering that the documentation states that its default iterator is `_.identity()` rather than `_.isEqual()`. This is the case for other find-methods, too.

It would be worth updating the documentation or am I missing something obvious here?

.internal/root.js not CSP-safe
body:
`lodash/.internal/root.js` includes `Function('return this')()` on line 7, which throws a [CSP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Content_Security_Policy) violation.

I was unable to use `lodash-cli` to create a custom build to exclude this feature.  Manually commenting out that last clause fixed the CSP violation.

Could a flag be added to the custom build process to drop that clause?

Related: #832.

title: Unexpected behaviour _.assign with getter/setter
body:
If I have a getter defined on my destination object, when assigning a source object the getter will not get overridden by the source. Is this by design?

Code to reproduce:

```
  var dest = { get a() { return 'initialValue';  } };
  var src = { a: '1', b: '2' };

  _.assign(dest, src);

  console.log(dest);
```
Expected result:

`{a: '1', b: '2' }`

Actual result:

`{a: 'initialValue', b: '2' }`

Fiddle demonstrating issue:

https://jsfiddle.net/q1gtg4z0/

title: Remove `map` example from `parseInt` and `trim`
body:
The examples where `parseInt` and `trim` are used with `map` are not valid anymore because the `guard` param was removed:
``` javascript
map(['6', '08', '10'], parseInt)
 // => [6, NaN, 2]
map(['  foo  ', '  bar  '], trim)
 // => ['  foo  ', '  bar  ']
```

title: The lodash method exported as lodash.isfunction does not work as expected with async function
body:
The lodash method _.isFunction exported as a Node.js module.
Does not work as expected with async function.

Code example here
https://runkit.com/embed/5c23g2rwhabp
```javascript
const lodashIsfunction = require("lodash.isfunction");
console.log(lodashIsfunction(() => null), 'Should be true'); // true
console.log(lodashIsfunction(async () => null), 'Async function should be true'); //false
```

The lodash works as expected
https://runkit.com/embed/z1dkat0izbgj
```javascript
var _ = require("lodash");
console.log(_.isFunction(() => null), 'Should be true'); // true
console.log(_.isFunction(async () => null), 'Async function should be true'); // true
```

title: debounced.cancel() example in documentation is incorrect
allow affecting all  elements in an array with set
body:
I am trying to use set to modify properties of objects that are inside arrays, and I'd like to be able to set on all elements in an array, like so:

`set(obj, 'a.b[*].c', 'foo')`

Note that in my actual use-case I have properties very deeply nested in multiple arrays, i.e I will need this functionality multiple levels deep (`a.b[*].c.d[*].e` etc.); so doing without this functionality means I have some nasty recursive functions to implement! :stuck_out_tongue_closed_eyes:

title: Faster/simpler isPlainObject check
body:
This runs up the prototype chain to check equivalency. When run in a cross-realm environment (differing contexts, iframes, etc), this ensures we're checking the value's prototype matches its context-specific instance of Object. 

This is faster than calling `toString()` on the constructor. There's still the `baseGetTag()` call, which does its own `toString()`, but this swaps out one for cross-realm stuff. It's also a bit simpler to understand, I think.

title: Fix typo in `inRange`
_.sum should type cast to Number or throw an error when summing strings
body:
# Expected:

The `sum` method is located on the Math section of the docs, which should mean that only numeric operations will be done. It should throw an error when the user try to sum a string value to an int as the default JS behavior will be a string typecast together with a concat (see Example 2 and Example 3).

# Code and Output

```
const _ = require('lodash')

console.log(_.sum([1, 1, 1])) // Example 1: Returns an int of value 3
console.log(_.sum([1, 1, '1'])) // Example 2: Returns a string of value 21
console.log(_.sum(['1', 1, 1])) // Example 3: Returns a string of value 111
```

# Fix suggestions:

- Check the input type and throw an error
- Typecast the input var to `Number` (_.sum will return a NaN if a string + int operation is done)
- Move _.sum from Math to Util section

title: _.clone throws on arrays, maps and sets whose constructor is no longer a function
[Feature Request] shorter form of iteratee
body:
var a = [1,2,3,4,5,6,7,8]
var b = [1,2,3,4,5,6,7,8,9]

Actual - long form
```
_.every(a, (n) => _.includes(b,n))
// true
_.every(b, (n) => _.includes(a,n))
// false
```

Actual - short form
```
_.every(a, _.includes)
// false
_.every(b, _.includes)
// false
```

Expected
```
_.every(a, _.includes)
// true
_.every(b, _.includes)
// false
```

title: lodash/fp get does not have an arity of two
body:
Hello,

I understand that you don't have time to write extensive documentation for the fp variant of lodash. Today I found that get is reported to have an arity of two. Seems that the default value option is missing on the FP variant.
Despite you are not going to add this to the FP version of get, I think you should spend some lines explaining what the "fixed arity" actually means. I though that it meant that the first function (the curried one) has an arity of X, representing the values the non-fp version takes, and then it returns a function taking the actual data.
Something like

```js
const getX = get('x','default')({x:'hello'}
```

It's hard to figure how functions work just by looking at the FP docs.

Regards

title: Workaround memory leak issue caused by slice method
body:
Recently we got several complains from our users about process crash due to OutOfMemory error. We've figured out, that the leak happens when one truncates a long string and passes it to the logger. More details here https://github.com/appium/appium/issues/9543

And [this Chromium bug report](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/v8/issues/detail?id=2869) contains more detailed description of what is happening under the hood. 

So, since we use `_.truncate` method to perform strings truncation, it might be a good idea to incorporate the fix/workaround here as well, so other module users don't suffer from this problem anymore.

title: Suggestion: add note in documentation for APIs that will become deprecated in a future version
body: For example, v5 will remove `_.omit` according to the [roadmap](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/wiki/Roadmap). It would be wonderful if the current documentation for `omit` contained a note for this function saying that it isn't long for this world, so people who might add call sites to their code are aware that their code will break when they upgrade.

title: Add string functions to compare with ignore case
body:
Would be great to have new functions that help with string comparisons (with ignore case) similar to https://www.npmjs.com/package/ignore-case.

```
_.stringEqual(string1, string2)
_.stringIncludes(string, searchString[, position])
_.stringStartsWith(string, searchString[, position])
_.stringEndsWith(string, searchString[, position])
_.stringIndexOf(string, searchString[, position])
```

Adding options to auto trim,  ignore case, and check for null, undefined, empty would be nice. 

By default enable ignore case, auto trim.

title: _.get not working properly on module exported object
Lodash fails to install on NPM
body:
I am trying to work on a project, and that project uses Lodash.

My problem is during 

```bash
finalize: sill finalize /node_modules/@types/lodash
```
Lodash does this:
```bash
npm ERR! path /node_modules/@types/lodash
npm ERR! code ENOENT
npm ERR! errno -2
npm ERR! syscall rename
npm ERR! enoent ENOENT: no such file or directory, rename '/node_modules/@types/lodash' -> '/node_modules/@types/.lodash.DELETE'
npm ERR! enoent This is related to npm not being able to find a file.
npm ERR! enoent
```

My log is attached here:
https://gist.github.com/AwesomeTech10/5883744574839b1489fe53070e4365c8

title: Flow with transform
_.trimStart didn't return as expect
body:
_.trimStart('replay_postman_order', 'replay_') expect return 'postman_order', but return 'ostman_order'. 

Test with version 4.17.4

title: _.isEqual is incorrect if object contains a property that has a hash value
body:
On comparing i'm receiving false even though the objects are the same (hex string)

```javascript
var a = { online: false,
  liveImg: null,
  __v: 0,
  links: 'https://api.twitch.tv/kraken/users/thirdechelon',
  logo: 'https://static-cdn.jtvnw.net/jtv_user_pictures/mollymayisme-profile_image-a219db7df7c6d5e1-300x300.jpeg',

  email: 'removed@email.com',
  displayName: 'mollymayisme',
  name: 'mollymayisme',
  registered: true,
  twitchtvId: '1234521412',
  _id: 59eac1ada4d6d2c6809ba4cc }
var b = { _id: 59eac1ada4d6d2c6809ba4cc,
  twitchtvId: '1234521412',
  registered: true,
  name: 'mollymayisme',
  displayName: 'mollymayisme',

  bio: 'dsadsadsadas',

  links: 'https://api.twitch.tv/kraken/users/thirdechelon',
  __v: 0,
  liveImg: null,
  online: false }
console.log(_.isEqual(a, b) // false
```

title: Cannot find module 'lodash.escaperegexp'
body:
Hi, i'm facing this error when attempting to run my project, i think this utility is broken that's why i got an exception in my project, early today it was working correctly without any error, i didn't add any code to the project, after i got this error, i removed the node-modules and reinstall the dependencies and still got it 

"lodash": "^4.17.2",

title: The wrap function expose the fn as the first param
body:
I want use _.wrap to add some behavior to my function. But the return value of _.wrap expose the fn param.

Example: 
![2017-10-30_142717](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4499997/32157880-2f66b87a-bd81-11e7-83d5-556490adf9d0.png)

p('text') work well.
But p(otherFn, 'text') will override the _.escape's behavior.

So how to get a clean wrapper only has the wrapped function's arguments list?

Regards.

title: _.create(null)
body:
Hello,

Looks like [9 months ago](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/b0980a90fc83bc92e040f905ebed8196f895949c) you refactored `_.create` to handle passing `null` as `prototype` just like `Object.create` does.

But, as today, version 4.17.4 still doesn't include this refactoring. When do you plan on publishing a new version?

Thanks for the good work 👍

title: clone behaviour on references
Slice
body:
`
start = start == null ? 0 : start
end = end === undefined ? length : end // Why not write the following situation =>end = end == null ? length : end 
`
